moves.1. e4 c5 2. Qh5: My friend must have been travel-weary. He never makes this kind of error.
moves.2... Nc6 3. Qxc5: The free Pawn is tempting, but White's development is already starting to lag.
moves.3... e6: Opening a line for the Bishop with tempo, as the Q is again attacked.
moves.4. Qc4 d5: White's Q would be best served to get behind the lines quickly so his other pieces can develop.
moves.5. exd5 exd5 6. Qe2+: Hoping for 6... Q-K2?, which would allow the exchange of Queens and give White time to develop his pieces.
moves.7. d3 Nf6: Black has 3 minor pieces developed to White's none. If he can attack quickly, White's defenses will be unready.
moves.8. Bg5: Finally developing a piece! But it's too little, too late.
moves.8... O-O 9. Qf3: Yet another Queen move! 9 N-QB3 would allow White to castle into relative safety. Now his King will be caught in the center. [If Black tries to win the Q via a pin on the K file, White has just enough time to get away: 9 N-QB3 R-K1 10 O-O-O B-Q3 and the White Q is free to escape the Rook's attack.]
moves.9... Nd4: Forcing the Q to move yet again!
moves.10. Qd1 Re8: With the threat of 11... B-N5 mate! Double checks are probably the most powerful weapon on the chessboard.
moves.11... a6: A waiting move, hoping White will fall into the trap.
moves.12. cxd4: Whoopsie! White got greedy and forgot that the pawn was the only thing preventing...
moves.12... Bb4#: ...this finish. My friend, in a mastery of understatement, sent this with a note reading "Not my best effort." I'd wholeheartedly agree.
